key_risks: Financial instability with $4.8 billion in net debt and a junk-rated credit profile
High sensitivity to macroeconomic factors such as rising interest rates and used car price volatility
Intense competition from traditional dealerships and online platforms
Customer complaints about vehicle quality, delivery delays, and customer service
controversies: Investigation for potential securities law violations, including accounting manipulation and insider trading
Legal challenges related to title processing delays, sales practices, and state licensing requirements
Accusations of financial improprieties by Hindenburg Research, leading to an 11% stock drop
social_issues: Poor customer service and billing issues, evidenced by numerous BBB complaints and negative reviews
Reliance on subprime auto loans and partnership with Ally Financial, raising ethical concerns about lending practices
governance_issues: Allegations of accounting manipulation and insider trading
Scrutiny over financial practices and compliance with regulatory requirements

sources.title: Carvana: A Father-Son Accounting Grift For The Ages
sources.snippet: The company has ~$4.8 billion in net debt and is junk-rated by ratings agencies. Carvana's business already faces major headwinds. Used vehicle prices have declined 20.3% in the past 3 years, according to the Manheim Price Index. Subprime auto loan delinquencies are now higher than during the Global Financial Crisis, per Fitch.
